title: Can I file an adversary proceeding to get my student loans discharged in bankruptcy, or do I need a lawyer to help me do this?
question: I am married, but I want to file individual bankruptcy to get my student loans discharged, due to undue hardship. I don't have much money to pay a lawyer, so I wanted to find out if I could do this on my own. I am a 61 year old woman, and I went back to school to try to start a career, because my husband's retirement will not be enough for us both to live on. I started grad school in 2007 in hopes of becoming an MFT. My school misrepresented the length of time it would take to complete the degree, and it ended up taking me five years. I have been unable to find employment, and my deferments are running out. I worry that they will take money out of our bank account if I default. I also worry that I will never be able to collect Social Security or Medicare. Thank you for any help!
answers: Student loan litigation is complicated and the student loan companies fight the cases very hard. There are also procedural rules you would need to learn, including possibly learning how to handle a trial. You would be far better off handling an experienced bankruptcy attorney who specializes in student loan litigation. You might also try working with the lenders directly to see if they would be willing to forgive your debt.

While I concur with the other answers that litigating the dischargeability of a student loan is a daunting task, one requiring the skills of a trained attorney, you may have other options. Given your current employment situation and age, i.e., nearing retirement, the prospects of being able to fulfill the obligations of the loan agreement are questionable. Trust me, I've seen similar situations. Seeking a discharge in bankruptcy is an option, but not necessarily the only way to address the issue.

You may wish to consider one of the income-based repayment options that allow you to have the payment vary, based upon your income, often with no payment required until your income exceeds a fixed threshold and then graduated as income fluctuates.

There are basically three types of plans: the Income-Based Repayment Plan (IBR Plan), the Pay As You Earn Repayment Plan, and the Income-Contingent Repayment Plan (ICR Plan), all three of which may help you bring the payment down to within your budget. You can learn more about these various repayment plans by visiting the informational website located at https://studentaid.ed.gov/repay-loans/understand/plans/income-drive

If, after you investigate your eligibility, you learn that you will not be able to qualify for one of the income-based options, you may actually have a better shot at obtaining a discharge in bankruptcy, as you will shown that you cannot qualify for any repayment plan due to lack of income. This tip is based on an actual case.

Ms. Larkin's answer is very much true to the point. Student Loans are very hard to discharge. There are some exceptions with respect to publicly funded student loans (as opposed to private student loans), where you may be able to obtain an hardship discharge from the actual lender rather than go through bankruptcy.

In order to do this in bankruptcy you will likely have to file an adversary proceeding, and, you will be held to a higher standard of proof in order to establish that there is no reasonable likelihood given your age and condition of your health, that you can ever repay this loan.

With respect to your savings, that would likely be up for grabs in a bankruptcy to the extent that they are not exempt.

Your SS can be offset against any loans owed to the US Government, but not to private student lenders with some exceptions. Generally when they do garnish wages, its limited to 15 percent.

Click on "Find a Lawyer" above. The couple thousand that you pay to a bankruptcy lawyer to get rid of an onerous debt like this may very well be worth it compared to the grief you'd be facing in your retirement.

Student Loan Litigation in the Adversary Proceeding process is difficult. Therefore I agree with some of the other comments made. However, it is not impossible. You will have to prove something more than a financial hardship, because that is all you have described. It may be a better alternative to consolidate your Federal Student Loans and get into an Income Based Repayment Plan. You should contact an attorney who has experience in the specialized area of student loan law, as well as bankruptcy law.

Are you required to have an attorney? No. Should you get one for your case? Yes.

You have to understand; student loan discharge is real litigation. There are no standard forms, you do discovery, get an expert witness and go to trial. And you are going to be against what we call TBL, tall building lawyers.
